creator: n.schmitt@scaet.de
text:
It would be helpful to a "content type dependend positive list of filters with 
exclusions" like the combination of "SetOutputFilter"/"RemoveOutputFilter".

Deflating content of type "application/x-pdf", retrieved from a backend system 
(in our case: from tomcat by jk2) produces harm due to the buggy coupling of 
AcrobatReader plugin and MS-IE. Sure - that coupling is not an apache.org 
issue. It just "influences".

Please have a look at the following Mozilla report

http://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=224296

There seems to be a problem, that we send content encoding
headers, but in fact are doing transfer encoding.

Due to this, the browser delivers the gzip'ed file to the acrobat
plugin, and this one isn't knowing how to handle the content.
creator: A.Schild@neatech.ch

text:
André, the sentence doesn't make any sense. Transfer-Encoding and
Content-Encoding are totally independent from each other. If Mozilla refuses to
process both headers, it's not HTTP/1.1 compliant. HTTP/1.1 clients *MUST*
support Transfer-Encoding chunked. And I bet, if they send "Accept-Encoding:
gzip" they should support gzip Content-Encoding as well.
However, this point has not really anything to do with a RemoveOutputFilter
directive....
creator: nd@perlig.de

text:
Moving bug to mod_mime where it belongs.

Fix should be part of updated filtering framework in due course, unless someone
wants to hack in something quick&dirty now.
creator: nick@webthing.com

text: This is obsolete since the introduction of mod_filter.
creator: nick@webthing.com
